text: Insomnia is a condition where you regularly have problems sleeping. It can often be improved by changing sleeping habits.

difficulty falling asleep, waking up several times during the night, lying awake at night, waking up early and unable to go back to sleep, feeling tired after waking, difficulty napping during the day, daytime tiredness, irritability, or concentration problems
stress, anxiety, or depression, noise, room too hot or cold, uncomfortable bed, alcohol, caffeine, nicotine, illegal drugs (cocaine, ecstasy), jet lag, shift work

maintain consistent sleep schedule, relax 1 hour before bed (bath, read), keep bedroom dark and quiet, exercise regularly during the day, ensure comfortable mattress, pillows, and covers, avoid alcohol, caffeine, tea, coffee 6 hours before bed, avoid large meals late at night, avoid exercising within 4 hours of bedtime, avoid devices before bed, avoid daytime naps, do not oversleep after a bad night's sleep
https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/insomnia/
COVID-19 is an illness caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, affecting the respiratory system and sometimes multiple organs.

dry cough, shortness of breath, loss of taste or smell, extreme fatigue, digestive issues: upset stomach, vomiting, diarrhea, headaches, body or muscle aches, fever or chills, coldlike symptoms: congestion, runny nose, sore throat

living with someone who has COVID-19, poorly ventilated crowded spaces, close contact >30 minutes with infected person, age 65+ or babies <6 months, weakened immune system, pregnancy, heart disease, hypertension, heart failure, stroke, diabetes, chronic kidney, liver, lung disease, mental health conditions, sickle cell disease, smoking, obesity
vaccination: Moderna, Pfizer-BioNTech, Novavax (approved for 65+ in US)
https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/coronavirus/symptoms-causes/syc-20479963
Back pain, particularly lower back pain, is very common. It usually improves within a few weeks but can sometimes last longer or recur.
muscle ache to shooting, burning, or stabbing pain, pain radiating down a leg, pain worsens with bending, twisting, lifting, standing, or walking

    "pain, tingling, weakness, or numbness in both legs",
    "numbness around genitals or buttocks",
    "difficulty urinating or loss of bladder/bowel control",
    "chest pain",
    "pain after a serious accident"
  ]
}
muscle or ligament strain, bulging or ruptured disks, arthritis, osteoporosis, ankylosing spondylitis
age (more common after 30–40), lack of exercise, excess weight, diseases like arthritis or cancer, improper lifting, psychological conditions, smoking
exercise regularly to build strength and flexibility, maintain a healthy weight, quit smoking, avoid movements that twist or strain the back, stand, sit, and lift smartly to protect your back
https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/back-pain/, https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/back-pain/symptoms-causes/syc-20369906
Eye redness, swelling, tears, discharge, and itching or discomfort are some of the common signs and symptoms of pink eye.

burn or feel gritty, pink or red color in the white of the eye, swelling of the eyelids or thin layer lining the eye, crusting of eyelids or lashes, especially in the morning, watery, teary eyes, eye discharge that may be clear, yellow, white, or green, itching, irritation, burning, sensation of something in the eye, contact lenses feel uncomfortable
Most common causes: viruses, bacteria, allergens. Less common: chemicals, contact lens wear, foreign bodies, pollution, fungi, ameba, parasites.

  "see_gp": [
    "baby has red, sticky eyes (urgent if under 30 days)",

    "symptoms do not clear within 7 days"
  ],

    "pain in your eyes",
    "sensitivity to light",
    "changes in vision",
    "very red eyes",
    "baby under 30 days old with red, sticky eyes",
    "blurred vision not improving after wiping discharge",
    "symptoms that get worse or do not improve",
    "bacterial conjunctivitis not improving after 24 hours of antibiotics",
    "weakened immune system"
  ],
  "call_911": []
}
You can get pink eye from touching infected hands, droplets from coughs/sneezes, contaminated objects or surfaces.
wash eyelids with clean cooled boiled water, wipe eyelashes with a clean cotton pad, hold a cold flannel on the eyes, do not wear contact lenses
wash hands regularly, wash pillowcases and face cloths, cover mouth when sneezing, do not share towels or pillows, do not rub eyes
https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/conjunctivitis/, https://www.cdc.gov/conjunctivitis/signs-symptoms/index.html
Dehydration means your body loses more fluids than you take in. It can become serious if untreated. Babies, children, and older adults are at higher risk.

{
  "infants_children": [
    "urinating less or no wet diapers for 3 hours",
    "dry mouth",
    "no tears when crying",
    "rapid heart rate",
    "sunken eyes, cheeks or soft spot",
    "lacking energy or crankiness",
    "skin that doesn't flatten after being pinched"
  ],
  "adults": [
    "extreme thirst",
    "urinating less",
    "dark-colored urine",
    "tiredness",
    "dizziness",
    "confusion",
    "skin that doesn't flatten after pinch",
    "sunken eyes or cheeks"
  ]
}
diabetes, sickness or diarrhea, heatstroke, alcohol consumption, excessive sweating, high temperature, medicines like diuretics
drink fluids regularly, start with small sips if feeling sick, gradually increase fluid intake

{
  "urgent_gp": [
    "unusual tiredness or drowsiness",
    "confusion or disorientation",
    "persistent dizziness",
    "dark yellow urine or urinating less",
    "fast breathing or heart rate",
    "few or no tears in infants",
    "sunken fontanelle in babies"
  ]
}
drink fluids regularly to keep urine pale and clear, increase intake during hot weather, illness, or exercise, children under 5 should get plenty of fluids
heat injury, urinary and kidney problems, seizures, low blood volume shock (hypovolemic shock)
https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/dehydration/, https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/dehydration/symptoms-causes/syc-20354086
Iron deficiency anemia is caused by lack of iron, often due to blood loss or pregnancy. It is treated with iron tablets and iron-rich foods.

extreme tiredness, weakness, paler than usual skin, chest pain, fast heartbeat, or shortness of breath, headache or dizziness, cold hands and feet, tongue irritation or soreness, brittle nails, restless legs syndrome, pica (craving non-food items such as ice, dirt, or clay), loss of appetite (especially in infants and children), odd smell cravings (rubber, detergents, cleaning agents)
blood loss, pregnancy, not enough iron in diet, difficulty absorbing iron

{
  "eat_more": [
    "dark-green leafy vegetables (watercress, curly kale)",
    "fortified cereals and bread",
    "meat",
    "dried fruit (apricots, prunes, raisins)",
    "pulses (beans, peas, lentils)"
  ],
  "eat_less": [
    "tea",
    "coffee",
    "milk and dairy",
    "foods high in phytic acid (wholegrain cereals)"
  ]
}
people with heavy periods, children and infants, vegetarians and vegans, people who had gastric bypass or stomach surgeries, people with digestive conditions, frequent blood donors
https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/iron-deficiency-anaemia/, https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/iron-deficiency-anemia/symptoms-causes/syc-20355034

A sore throat is pain or irritation of the throat. Swallowing often makes it feel worse. The most common cause of a sore throat, also called pharyngitis, is a viral infection, such as a cold or the flu. A sore throat from a virus goes away on its own.
Painful to swallow, Dry and scratchy throat, Redness in the back of your mouth, Bad breath, A mild cough, Swollen neck glands, Children may experience high temperature and become less active
Cough, Runny nose, Hoarseness, Conjunctivitis
Viruses (most common cause), Group A Streptococcus bacteria (strep throat), Allergies, Smoking or exposure to secondhand smoke
Clean your hands, Avoid close contact with people who have respiratory infections, Don't smoke and avoid secondhand smoke

Gargle warm salty water (not for children), Drink plenty of water, Eat cool or soft foods, Avoid smoke, Suck ice cubes or ice lollies (not for young children due to choking risk), Rest
Tobacco smoke exposure, Allergies, Chemical exposure, Frequent sinus infections, Being near other people in grouped settings, Weak immune system
https://www.cdc.gov/sore-throat/about/, https://www.nhs.uk/symptoms/sore-throat/, https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/sore-throat/symptoms-causes/syc-20351635
A panic attack is a sudden episode of intense fear that triggers severe physical reactions even when there is no real danger. It can be very frightening and may mimic a heart attack.

sense of impending doom or danger, fear of loss of control or death, rapid, pounding heart rate, sweating, trembling or shaking, shortness of breath or tightness in throat, chills or hot flashes, nausea or abdominal cramping, chest pain, headache, dizziness, lightheadedness or faintness, numbness or tingling, feeling of unreality or detachment
genetics, major stress, sensitive temperament prone to negative emotions, changes in brain function

late teens or early adulthood onset, more common in women, family history of panic attacks or disorder, major life stress (death or serious illness of loved one), traumatic events (sexual assault, serious accident), major life changes (divorce, birth of a child), smoking or excessive caffeine, history of childhood physical or sexual abuse

development of specific phobias, frequent medical visits for health concerns, avoidance of social situations, problems at work or school, depression, anxiety, and other psychiatric disorders, increased risk of suicide, alcohol or substance misuse, financial problems
early treatment of panic attacks, adhere to treatment plan to prevent relapses, regular physical activity may help protect against anxiety
https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/panic-attacks/symptoms-causes/syc-20376021
Anaphylaxis is a life-threatening allergic reaction that happens quickly, often due to food, medicine, or insect stings. Immediate medical attention is required.

swelling of throat and tongue, difficulty breathing or very fast breathing, difficulty swallowing, tight throat or hoarse voice, wheezing, coughing, noisy breathing, fatigue or confusion, feeling faint, dizzy or fainting, cold skin, blue, grey or pale skin, lips or tongue, swollen, raised or itchy rash

use adrenaline auto-injector if available, call 911 immediately, lie down, raise legs; if struggling to breathe, raise shoulders or sit slowly, remove insect sting if applicable, use second injector after 5 minutes if symptoms persist, do not stand or walk even if feeling better

avoid known allergens, carry 2 adrenaline auto-injectors and check expiry dates, practice injector use with trainer, teach others how to use injector, wear medical alert jewellery, alert healthcare providers to allergies
previous anaphylaxis, allergies or asthma, heart disease or mastocytosis
foods (nuts, milk, eggs, fish, sesame seeds), medicines (antibiotics, NSAIDs), insect stings (wasp, bee), anaesthetics, latex, sometimes unknown
https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/anaphylaxis/, https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/anaphylaxis/symptoms-causes/syc-20351468
A migraine tends to be a very bad headache with a throbbing pain on one side of the head.

Cause is unknown. More likely if you have a family member with migraines. Triggers include period, anxiety, depression, stress, tiredness, skipping meals, caffeine, lack of exercise.
Sleep or lie down in a dark room, Avoid triggers, Stay hydrated, Limit caffeine and alcohol, Keep healthy weight, Eat regular meals, Exercise regularly, Get plenty of sleep, Manage stress
Migraines usually last 2 hours to 3 days. Some symptoms start 2 days before the headache and last after the headache stops. Menstrual migraines are common.
Family history, Teenage onset, peak in 30s, Women are three times more likely than men, Hormonal changes
https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/migraine/, https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/migraine-headache/symptoms-causes/syc-20360201
Type 2 diabetes is a condition where blood sugar levels are too high. Symptoms develop gradually and may be similar to type 1 diabetes but are usually slower to appear.
feeling very tired, peeing more than usual, feeling thirsty all the time, unexplained weight loss, blurred vision, cuts or wounds taking longer to heal, itching around genitals or recurrent thrush

age: over 40 for white people, over 25 for South Asian, Chinese, Black African, or Black Caribbean ethnic background, family history (parent or sibling with diabetes), overweight and physically inactive, high blood pressure
eat healthy foods with more fiber, fruits, vegetables, and whole grains, increase physical activity, lose excess weight (even 7% reduction lowers risk)
damage to blood vessels (coronary heart disease, stroke), foot problems (ulcers, infections, possible amputation), sight problems (diabetic retinopathy, blindness), kidney problems, gum disease

A common skin condition causing itchy skin. Most common in young children. Cannot be cured but treatment can manage symptoms.
itchy skin, dry, cracked, crusty, scaly or thickened skin, skin color changes (red, white, purple, grey, lighter or darker), blistering or bleeding, flare-ups and periods of improvement
elbows, knees, hands, face (babies and toddlers)
unknown exact cause, parent with atopic eczema, family history of asthma or hay fever
allergens or irritants (soap, detergents, fabrics, pets, pollen, mites), heat or temperature changes, skin infections, stress, hormonal changes

avoid triggers such as soaps, detergents, certain fabrics, pets, apply moisturisers frequently (at least twice daily), wash with emollient instead of soap, keep cool, keep nails short, use anti-scratch mittens for babies, rub gently instead of scratching, avoid sharing emollients, use spoon or pump dispenser for emollients, do not use aqueous cream, do not change diet unless advised, avoid smoking or open flames near emollients
https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/atopic-eczema/
A stroke occurs when blood stops flowing to a part of the brain. It can affect speech, movement, and cognition, and is a medical emergency requiring immediate hospital care.

face weakness – one side droops, difficulty smiling, arm weakness – unable to lift or hold arms due to weakness/numbness, speech problems – slurred or confused speech, weakness or numbness down one side of the body, blurred or lost vision in one/both eyes, difficulty speaking or finding words, confusion or memory loss, dizziness or falls, severe headache, nausea or vomiting

age over 50, Black or South Asian ethnicity, sickle cell disease, unhealthy lifestyle, migraines, combined contraceptive pill, pregnancy with pre-eclampsia, recent childbirth, high blood pressure, diabetes, atrial fibrillation, high cholesterol, transient ischemic attack (TIA/mini stroke), cardiovascular disease, smoking or secondhand smoke, obstructive sleep apnea, family history of stroke or heart attack, COVID-19 infection

control high blood pressure, reduce cholesterol and saturated fat intake, quit tobacco, manage diabetes, maintain healthy weight, eat fruits and vegetables, exercise regularly, drink alcohol in moderation, treat obstructive sleep apnea, avoid illicit drugs
paralysis, trouble talking or swallowing, memory or cognitive issues, emotional changes, pain, behavior and self-care changes
https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/stroke/, https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/stroke/symptoms-causes/syc-20350113

Hay fever, also called allergic rhinitis, causes cold-like symptoms such as a runny nose, itchy eyes, congestion, sneezing and sinus pressure. It is caused by an allergic response to harmless substances (allergens).

sneezing, itchy nose, itchy, red and watery eyes, cough, itchy roof of the mouth, runny nose and nasal congestion, postnasal drip, swollen, bruised-appearing skin under eyes (allergic shiners), extreme tiredness and fatigue
pollen from trees, grass, and weeds, house dust mites, animals such as dogs and cats, mould, wood dust, flour dust, and latex, family history of allergies, eczema, or asthma
avoid triggers if possible, antihistamines, decongestant nasal sprays or drops (not for children under 6), salt water nasal sprays or solutions, do not use decongestants for more than a week

wear wraparound sunglasses during pollen season, use hypoallergenic bedding and wash at 60C+, dust with damp cloth and use HEPA vacuum, wash pets every 2 weeks and groom outside, wash pet bedding regularly, keep home dry and ventilated, do not allow pets in bedrooms, avoid going outside or drying clothes outside during high pollen count
https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/hay-fever/symptoms-causes/syc-20373039, https://www.cdc.gov/climate-health/php/effects/allergens-and-pollen.html
Depression is a mood disorder that causes a persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest.

feelings of sadness, tearfulness, emptiness or hopelessness, angry outbursts, irritability or frustration, loss of interest or pleasure in normal activities, sleep disturbances (insomnia or sleeping too much), tiredness and lack of energy, reduced appetite and weight loss or increased cravings and weight gain, anxiety, agitation or restlessness, slowed thinking, speaking or body movements, feelings of worthlessness or guilt, trouble thinking, concentrating, making decisions or remembering things, frequent thoughts of death, suicidal thoughts or attempts, unexplained physical problems (back pain, headaches)

age: teens, 20s or 30s (can occur at any age), more common in women, personality traits: low self-esteem, dependent, self-critical, pessimistic, traumatic or stressful events, family history of depression, bipolar disorder, alcoholism, suicide, LGBTQ+ in unsupportive environment, history of other mental health disorders, alcohol or drug abuse, serious or chronic illness, certain medications (high blood pressure meds, sleeping pills)

excess weight or obesity leading to heart disease or diabetes, pain or physical illness, alcohol or drug misuse, anxiety, panic disorder or social phobia, family, relationship or work/school difficulties, social isolation, suicidal feelings or attempts, self-mutilation, premature death from medical conditions
control stress and build resilience, reach out to family and friends, seek treatment early, consider long-term maintenance treatment to prevent relapse
https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/depression/symptoms-causes/syc-20356007
High blood pressure, or hypertension, can lead to serious problems such as heart attacks or strokes. A reading of 130/80 mm Hg or higher is generally considered high.
usually none, headaches, blurred vision, chest pain, shortness of breath, nosebleeds

age (risk increases with age, men more until 64, women more after 65), race (higher in Black people, develops earlier than in white people), family history of hypertension, obesity or overweight, lack of exercise, tobacco use or vaping, high salt intake, low potassium levels, excess alcohol, stress, chronic conditions (kidney disease, diabetes, sleep apnea), pregnancy
eat a healthy, balanced diet, exercise regularly (at least 150 minutes/week), lose weight if overweight, limit salt intake, limit alcohol intake to 14 units/week, limit caffeine, do not smoke

Viral gastroenteritis is an intestinal infection that includes signs and symptoms such as watery diarrhea, stomach cramps, nausea or vomiting, and sometimes fever.
watery, usually nonbloody diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps and pain, occasional muscle aches or headache, low-grade fever

Caused by a virus. Symptoms may appear within 1–3 days after infection and usually last 1–2 days, sometimes up to 14 days. Spread through contaminated food or water or shared utensils, towels or food.
dehydration, severe dehydration requiring IV fluids, rarely death

get your child vaccinated, wash your hands thoroughly, use separate personal items, prepare food safely, disinfect hard surfaces, avoid touching laundry exposed to virus, check child care center hygiene practices

stay at home and rest, drink plenty of fluids, give babies small frequent feeds, give sips of water between feeds, eat when able, avoid fatty/spicy foods, take paracetamol if needed, do not drink fruit juice or fizzy drinks, do not weaken baby formula, do not give antidiarrheal medicine to children under 12, do not give aspirin to children under 16

Asthma is a common condition that affects breathing. It cannot be cured, but when well treated, symptoms should not cause problems.
wheezing, coughing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, symptoms worse at night or early morning
exercise, air pollution, cold air, pollen, dust, mould, animals, allergies

Not fully understood. More likely if you have allergies, family history of asthma/allergies, prematurity, exposure to pollution or smoke as a child, childhood respiratory illnesses, or are overweight. Can also be caused by workplace chemical exposure.

always have inhaler, use inhalers as recommended, avoid triggers, exercise regularly, keep a healthy weight, get vaccinations such as flu vaccine, do not smoke, check medicines with doctor or pharmacist
https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/asthma/
Heartburn is a burning feeling in the chest caused by stomach acid travelling up towards the throat (acid reflux). Recurrent heartburn may indicate gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

heartburn – burning sensation in the middle of the chest, unpleasant sour taste in the mouth, cough or hiccups that keep coming back, hoarse voice, bad breath, bloating and feeling sick, backwash of food or sour liquid in the throat, upper belly or chest pain, trouble swallowing (dysphagia), sensation of a lump in the throat, nighttime acid reflux: ongoing cough, laryngitis, new or worsening asthma

certain foods and drinks: coffee, tomatoes, alcohol, chocolate, fatty or spicy foods, being overweight, smoking, pregnancy, stress and anxiety, hormonal changes (progesterone, oestrogen), certain medications such as anti-inflammatory painkillers, hiatus hernia, stomach ulcer, bacterial infection in the stomach

eat smaller, more frequent meals, lose weight if overweight, relaxation techniques, avoid food and drink that trigger symptoms, do not eat within 3–4 hours before bed, avoid tight clothing around waist, do not smoke, limit alcohol, do not stop prescribed medicines without consulting a doctor
esophagitis – inflammation of esophagus tissue, esophageal stricture – narrowing of esophagus, Barrett esophagus – precancerous changes in esophagus
https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/heartburn-and-acid-reflux/, https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/gerd/symptoms-causes/syc-20361940
Flu (influenza) is a viral infection of the nose, throat, and lungs (respiratory system). It is distinct from gastrointestinal 'stomach flu' illnesses that cause vomiting or diarrhea.
Viral infection (influenza viruses)

fever or feeling feverish/chills, cough, sore throat, runny or stuffy nose, muscle or body aches, headaches, fatigue (tiredness), vomiting (more common in children), diarrhea (more common in children)
Appears quickly within a few hours, Affects more than just the nose and throat, Causes significant fatigue and malaise

Typically lasts 2 days to 2 weeks.

Sinus infections, Ear infections, Pneumonia (viral or bacterial), Myocarditis (heart inflammation), Encephalitis (brain inflammation), Myositis or rhabdomyolysis (muscle inflammation/breakdown), Multi-organ failure (respiratory or kidney failure), Sepsis, Worsening of chronic medical conditions (asthma, heart disease)
Adults 65 years or older, People with chronic medical conditions (asthma, diabetes, heart disease), Pregnant women, Children under 5, especially under 2
Highly contagious. Symptoms typically begin 1–4 days after infection. Transmission can occur even before symptoms appear.

Rest and sleep, Keep warm, Use acetaminophen/paracetamol or ibuprofen to reduce fever and aches, Ensure hydration (urine should be light yellow or clear), Give age-appropriate fever reducers to children if needed

UTIs are common infections that happen when bacteria, often from the skin or rectum, enter the urethra and infect the urinary tract.

pain or burning when peeing, needing to pee more often, needing to pee more often at night, urgency, cloudy pee, blood in pee, lower tummy pain or back pain, high or very low temperature, tiredness or weakness, pressure or cramping in the groin or lower abdomen, symptoms of kidney infection: fever, chills, lower back/side pain, nausea or vomiting, dark or smelly pee, children: high temperature, irritability, feeding issues, bedwetting, older adults: confusion, agitation, worsening incontinence, new shivering

Usually caused by bacteria from poo entering the urinary tract. Women have a shorter urethra making infection more likely. Other causes include sex, pregnancy, urinary blockages, catheter use, constipation, enlarged prostate, weakened immune system, dehydration.

A tension-type headache causes mild to moderate pain that's often described as feeling like a tight band around the head. A tension-type headache is the most common type of headache, yet its causes aren't well understood.

pain on both sides of your head, face or neck, feeling like something is pressing on your head or being tightened around it, the affected area may feel tender and your head may hurt more when touched, feeling of tightness or pressure across the forehead or on the sides and back of the head, tenderness in the scalp, neck and shoulder muscles, you should be able to continue doing daily activities without making the headache worse
Common causes include stress, sleep problems, caffeine. Taking painkillers for headaches too often or for a long time can also cause headaches (overuse or rebound headaches).
Tension headaches last at least 30 minutes but they can last much longer, sometimes for several days.

Constipation is a change in bowel movements, including infrequent or difficult-to-pass stools. It is common across all ages and can usually be managed with diet and lifestyle changes.

fewer than 3 bowel movements in a week or less frequent than usual, poo is dry, hard, or lumpy, unusually large or small, straining or pain when passing stool, feeling of incomplete emptying, rectum feels blocked, need to use a finger to pass stool, stomach ache, bloating, or feeling sick, behavior changes in older adults, people with dementia or learning disabilities
Chronic constipation: symptoms for three months or longer

low fiber diet, not drinking enough fluids, sedentary lifestyle, ignoring urge to go to toilet, changes in diet or daily routine, side effect of medication, stress, anxiety, or depression, pregnancy or postnatal changes, age over 65, rare medical conditions: diverticular disease, bowel cancer

eat high-fiber foods: vegetables, fruits, beans, whole grains, reduce low-fiber foods: processed foods, dairy, meats, drink plenty of fluids, stay physically active, do not ignore urge to defecate, establish regular toilet routine
older age, female, low physical activity, mental health conditions (depression, eating disorders), use of opioid painkillers

Angina is pain or tightness in the chest, often indicating a heart problem. It usually occurs when the heart does not get enough blood, commonly due to coronary heart disease.

sudden pain in chest, neck, shoulders, jaw, or arms, tightness, squeezing, pressure, or dull ache, may cause nausea, breathlessness, dizziness, or sweating, attacks usually last less than 10 minutes, often triggered by exercise, stress, emotion, or cold temperatures
stop activity and rest, use prescribed angina medicine (usually glyceryl trinitrate/GTN), take a second dose after 5 minutes if symptoms persist, call 911 if symptoms remain after the second dose

age: men ≥45, women ≥55, smoking, alcohol >14 units/week, obesity or overweight, high blood pressure or high cholesterol, previous heart problems (heart attack, arrhythmia), family history of heart problems, other conditions: diabetes, arthritis, kidney disease

avoid triggers like stress, cold temperatures, or large meals, carry and use angina medicine as instructed, quit smoking, maintain healthy weight, eat balanced diet, stay as active as symptoms allow, moderate alcohol consumption
https://www.cdc.gov/high-blood-pressure/data-research/facts-stats/index.html#cdc_facts_stats_high-blood-pressure-differences-by-sex-and-race
A heart attack is a serious medical emergency in which the blood supply to the heart is suddenly blocked, usually by a blood clot.

chest pain: pressure, heaviness, tightness, or squeezing, pain spreading to arms (usually left), jaw, neck, back, or tummy, lightheadedness or dizziness, sweating, shortness of breath, nausea or vomiting, anxiety, coughing or wheezing, some people may experience minor pain similar to indigestion
coronary heart disease

age: men ≥45, women ≥55, tobacco use, long-term high blood pressure, high cholesterol or triglycerides, obesity, diabetes, metabolic syndrome, family history of heart attacks, physical inactivity, unhealthy diet: high in sugars, animal fats, processed foods, trans fats, and salt, stress (e.g., extreme anger), illegal drug use: cocaine, amphetamines, autoimmune conditions: rheumatoid arthritis, lupus
quit smoking, maintain healthy weight, exercise regularly (≥150 minutes/week), eat low-fat, high-fibre diet with ≥5 portions of fruits/vegetables daily, moderate alcohol consumption
Call 911 immediately if heart attack is suspected
https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/heart-attack/, https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/heart-attack/symptoms-causes/syc-20373106
Appendicitis is swelling and infection in the appendix. It usually causes pain in the lower right side of the abdomen and needs urgent hospital treatment.

sudden pain in lower right belly or around belly button shifting to lower right, pain worsens with coughing, walking, or jarring movements, nausea and vomiting, loss of appetite, low-grade fever that may rise, constipation or diarrhea, bloating, gas, peeing more than usual, sudden confusion in older people
age 10–30, slightly higher risk in men
wound infection, bleeding, scar tissue (adhesions) causing bowel blockage, abscess at site of appendix removal, stump appendicitis (in remaining appendix)
soreness or redness around wound getting worse, bleeding or pus from wound, high temperature
https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/appendicitis/symptoms-causes/syc-20369543, https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/appendicitis/
Sinusitis is swelling of the sinuses, usually caused by an infection. It is common and usually clears up on its own within 4 weeks.

pain, swelling, and tenderness around cheeks, eyes, or forehead, blocked or runny nose, reduced sense of smell, green or yellow nasal mucus, high temperature, headache, toothache, bad breath, cough, pressure in ears, nasal voice or snoring, children may be irritable, have feeding difficulties, and breathe through mouth
rest, drink plenty of fluids, take painkillers such as paracetamol or ibuprofen (not aspirin for children under 16), avoid triggers of allergies, do not smoke, clean nose with salt water solution
https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/sinusitis-sinus-infection/
A cold is a viral infection of the upper respiratory tract (also called an upper respiratory infection or URI). Colds usually last less than a week and are caused by different respiratory viruses.
Runny nose or nasal congestion, Cough, Sneezing, Sore throat, Headache, Mild body aches, Fever (usually low grade in older children and adults)
Viral infection most likely the Rhinoviruses.

Most viral diseases spread through droplets during coughing and sneezing. Some viruses can also spread through close personal contact, such as shaking hands with an infected person and then touching your eyes, nose, or mouth. Many respiratory viruses, like influenza virus and RSV, usually circulate during winter, but other viruses that can also cause cold symptoms circulate during spring, summer, or fall.
Usually lasts less than a week and the symptoms peak within 2 to 3 days of infection.
